subject: RE: [junit] Possible TestCaseClassLoader bug
msgSnippet: I posted a fixed dynamically reloadable classloader for the AWT/Swing runners a while back: http://users.rcn.com/scottstirling/2003/07/19.html#a61 The textui
messageBody:
I posted a fixed dynamically reloadable classloader for the AWT/Swing runners a while back:
http://users.rcn.com/scottstirling/2003/07/19.html#a61

The textui runner calls System.exit() after each run, so I didn't see any point in messing with it. It's easier to write new test runners from scratch, believe me. If you want console based JUnit runs, check out Ant's <junit> tasks. They can do tons of stuff that the textui runner can't.

JUnit's classloader problems are pretty well known by now and well-documented in the FAQ, my blog, Stu Halloway's blog, etc.

I fixed the class loader by making it follow the Java 2 delegation model. Bill Venner's suggests not even extending ClassLoader. Just create a new URLClassLoader between runs. There's a lot of stuff in the list archives about all this.

HTH,

Scott Stirling
Framingham, MA

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Malcolm Sparks [mailto:malcolm@...]
>
> <off-topic>
> If you really want to write your own JUnit class loader I would
> recommend that you write it from scratch, and create an implementation
> that only overrides ClassLoader.findClass(String name), specifying
> the classes you want to include rather than classes you want
> to exclude.
> Keep the system CLASSPATH set to just the classes you need
> for your test
> runner and nothing else. This would align your class loader to Sun
> recommendations on such things. I don't know why JUnit's class loading
> is written the way it is, perhaps someone could enlighten me, but I
> expect it is because the code pre-dates JDK 1.2, when the Java class
> loading model was no as stable.
> </off-topic>
